comments:
Build 20020214

I tried to rename a Java project.

After a while, an error dialog appeared.  The title of the dialog 
was 'Refactoring'.

The content of the dialog was:

-----------------------------------------
An unexpected exception has been caught while processing the change 'Rename 
Java Project com.ibm.etools.fcm to:com.ibm.etools.fcm_2.0.0'.  The exceptions 
message is:

{1}

Press "Undo" to undo all succesfully executed changes
Press "Abort" to abort the refactoring
-----------------------------------------

There was also an error logged to my .log file.  From the exception I think 
that I know what the problem was: one of the files in the project was open in 
another program, so Eclispe was unable to delete it.  (The log file is included 
below.)

There are several problems here:

#1 - the error dialog is incomplete.  What's with the '{1}'?  You should tell 
me what the real problem is!

#2 - the error message is grammatically incorrect.  'exceptions' should 
be 'exception's', and the colon after the 'to:' is unnecessary.

#3 - there's no need to delete any files when I rename a project.  Just rename 
the directory.  I can do this from Windows Explorer, so Eclipse should be able 
to do it too.

.log file:
-------------------------------
Log: Fri Mar 22 15:00:10 EST 2002
4 org.eclipse.jdt.ui 1 Internal Error

#4 - After I logged this, I pressed the 'Undo' button.  Eclipse took a while to 
rebuild everything, and I thought that it had finished.  However on examing the 
file system I discovered that it had, in fact, renamed the project 
succesfully!  The Undo had no apparent effect.

Tod, 

Please try this case in the latest 2.0 builds. From the description it looks 
like a problem with the JDT refactoring but it may point to a deeper problem.

Could not replicate in build 20020501. Moving to JDT UI as I am not sure how to 
get this condition.
this code has fully changed in the latest - closing this bug
